ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: In situ ZnO–PVA nanocomposite coated microfluidic chips for biosensing

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Microfluidic chips with integrated fluid and optical connectors have been generated via a simple PDMS master-mould technique. In situ coating using a Zinc oxide polyvinylalcohol based sol–gel method results in ultrathin nanocomposite layers on the fluid channels, which makes them strongly hydrophilic and minimizes auto contamination of the chips by injected fluorescent biomarkers.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is favoured for the fabrication of lab-on-chip devices because it is optically transparent with low fluorescence yield [1, 2], cost effective and can easily be soft-lithographically processed into microfluidic devices containing complex channel structures [3, 4]. However, native PDMS surfaces are hydrophobic and can adsorb small molecules. In particular, undesirable irreversible adsorption of dye molecules that are used as labelling agents for microbiological applications limits the applicability of PDMS in chemical and biological analysis [2].

Surface modification of PDMS to impart hydrophobicity has been addressed by several authors with a variety of methods [5]. The oxidation of PDMS via plasma discharge and UV/ozone treatments to create hydrophilic surface radicals like SiO x or Si–OH is certainly among the most versatile methods [6, 7]. A drawback is, however, the instability of the oxidised PDMS surface in air, reported by McDonald et al. [8] who showed that the hydrophilic character is lost in air after few hours ageing. More recently, the sol–gel method has been used to modify the surface chemistry with SiO x species [9], or to integrate SiO2 nanoparticles in the PDMS matrix [10]. Coating with other oxides such as TiO2, ZrO2, VO2 [10] or with a glass-like layer has also been reported [12, 17]. According to Roman et al. [11], TiO2 and ZrO2 coatings change water contact angles (WCA) from 110° to 61° and 90°, respectively, while VO x , although more hydrophilic, impaired the optical transparency of the chip.

In this article, we implement a microfluidic platform based on PDMS with integrated fluid and optical connectors. We use a sol–gel method to coat the channel walls in situ (i.e., while the chip is closed) with an ultrathin, adherent, and stable ZnO-nanocomposite layer. The targeted amphiphilic properties were obtained via modification of the ZnO precursor with a small amount of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA). The ZnO–PVA nanocomposite layers show optical transparency, very low WCA, and low affinity for irreversible dye molecule adsorption.

The usefulness of this coating method is proven by exposing the microfluidic chip to the hydrophobic dye SYTO 13 [13], which is a cell permanent nucleic acid stain that exhibits bright, green fluorescence upon binding to nucleic acids. SYTO 13 dye penetrates the uncoated PDMS chip matrix and accumulates on microfluidic channel walls. Upon coating, this effect is drastically reduced.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The fabrication of microfluidic platforms on the basis of PDMS is essentially a three step process, including SU8 master production, PDMS replication, and PDMS sealing. The drawn pattern of the microfluidic channels is transferred into hard baked SU8 using simple photolithography (100 μm high structures) [14]. The design used in this article consists of five straight channels, each 200 μm wide.

By moulding PDMS onto the SU8 structured Si wafer master, the microfluidic channel pattern can be replicated repeatedly, producing many chips from a single master [15]. Within the same production step, both optical and fluid connectors are moulded into the chip [16] (see Fig. 1). Liquid PDMS (Sylgard 184, Dow Coring) is poured into a custom-made mould and cured at 100 °C for 30 min. Finally, the chip is sealed with a thin (~5 mm) PDMS sheet using plasma activation [6, 17].
Fig. 1
Schematic (left) and image (right) showing PDMS chip (a) with optical fibers (b) and fluid connectors (c) mounted on a custom-made chip chuck (d) push-fit connector platform

To coat the channels of the chips, we have applied a sol–gel method. Zinc acetate was dissolved in water to yield a 0.4 M solution. After homogenization by magnetic stirring, a small amount of polyvinyl alcohol (10 g/l) was added and homogenized for 30 min. The PDMS chips were used as processed, i.e., without previous surface treatments. The solution was pumped into the sealed PDMS chip using the set-up outlined in Fig. 2 which consists of a peristaltic pump and tube connections. The sol was pumped through the closed channels for 2 min and excess sol was removed by pumping it out of the channels at the end of the processing. The chips with the coated channels were subsequently dried for 16 h in a dry box at 125 °C.
Fig. 2
Schematic drawing of the coating set-up for PDMS channels

The coated channels were characterized using a scanning electron microscope (Zeiss, Ultra Plus, Germany) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX, INCA, Oxford, UK). The optical properties of the coated chip were obtained in transmission mode using a photospectrometer (lambda 35, Perkin Elmer). Water contact angle (WCA) measurements were done using a contact angle microscope (Data Physics, OCA 15 plus, Germany) and the sessile drop method.

The effect of the ZnO–PVA coating on dye molecule absorption was investigated by mounting two identical PDMS chips (coated and uncoated) under a fluorescence microscope (Nikon Eclipse ME600) and pumping a SYTO13 solution (10 μl/ml in PBS buffer) through the chips at a constant rate (20 μl/min). The 435.8 nm G-line of an Hg lamp was used for fluorescence excitation and long-exposure (5s integration) images were obtained at a fixed position of the channel, using 10× magnification and a CCD camera. The chips were first filled with pure PBS buffer (reference), followed by injection of the SYTO13 solution (starting time = 0). After injection of 1 ml solution (55 min), the system was flushed by injecting 1 ml PBS buffer (total time = 120 min). Images were obtained every 5 min during staining and flushing, while the Hg lamp was shuttered between measurements to prevent bleaching. Using image analysis software, line scans of light intensity were obtained across the fluid channel.

In addition to physical measurements, the dye contamination was investigated using real biological samples. For that purpose, an overnight culture in BHI medium of Listeria innocua (DSMZ no. 20649), a non- pathogenic bacteria strain, was used. Prior to the experiments, the bacteria were diluted in PBS buffer. For the detection of the bacteria, a FACScan flow cytometer (Becton–Dickinson, Germany) was used. The sample injection system of the cytometer was modified, so as to enable direct connection of the chip outlet with the sample needle. All the fluids and bacteria suspensions were pumped with a syringe pump (JTES Biotech, Germany) through the chip and then into the flow cytometer at 20 μl/min. The following signals were detected: Forward Scatter light (FSC), Side Scatter light (SSC), and green fluorescence of cells. For analysing the measurements, the bacteria population was identified and gated in the FSC–SSC plot. Then the green fluorescence mean for all events in this gate was determined. In every sample, 20,000 bacteria were measured.

As controls, pure PBS buffer and unstained bacteria were measured first in the cytometer without a chip. Then the outlet of the non-coated chip was directly connected to the sample needle of the cytometer and pure PBS was pumped through the chip to remove all non-cellular particles until no differences in the flow cytometric analysis, compared to the control, could be detected. In the next step, a fixed volume of a SYTO® 13 solution was injected into the chip (1 μmol in PBS buffer). Without rinsing the system, unstained bacteria were then continuously pumped through the chip and measured with the cytometer at six regular intervals. After cleaning of the whole system, the coated chip was tested using the same procedure.

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and EDX analysis of cross sections from a coated channel are shown in Figs. 3, 4. The nanocomposite PVA–ZnO coating layer with approximately 200 nm thickness is homogeneous, crack free, and shows high plasticity as exemplified in the cross section of Fig. 4 (circled area).
Fig. 3
Scanning electron micrographs of the coated channel top cover with low magnification and high magnification (inset)
Fig. 4
Scanning electron microscopy image of cross section of the coated channel with EDX analysis as inset

The ZnO-nanocomposite layer is built by the formation of a Zn–O-network including dipolar bonding of Zn with −OH functional groups of PVA. It most probably adsorbs on PDMS via −OH functional groups as it is well known that PVA can adsorb on hydrogenated and protonated surfaces via these functional groups. Cross linking of the polymer chains in the presence of water should then form the polymeric layer that, according to Patil and Joshi [18], is able to confine small ZnO entities within its loops. A schematic drawing of a possible composite structure obtained after the drying treatment is given in Fig. 5.
Fig. 5
Schematic drawing of a possible ZnO–PVA nanocomposite structure obtained after drying. The ZnO entities are confined within the PVA polymerized network

Further characterization of the coating includes WCA measurements using the sessile drop method [19] on different regions of the chip surface. The measured WCA of the coated chip was as low as 30° compared to 106° on the uncoated chips, Fig. 6. The hydrophilic character of the coating most probably arises from the PVA chain network that wraps the ZnO nanoparticles.
Fig. 6
Water contact angle measured on the surface of a uncoated and b coated PDMS chip

The closed channel chip (2 cm length and 200 μm width) is coated with ZnO-nanocomposite as shown in Fig. 2. After removing the chip cover, we place the chip with the channel, parallel to a microscope equipped with a camera, and follow the flow mechanism of a water droplet (0.2 μl volume) in the coated channel. Figure 7 shows snapshots of the droplet after 10, 120, and 210 s illustrating the hydrophilic character of the coated channel walls and the hydrophobic one of the uncoated surface outside of the channel. The droplet, which is larger than the channel width, becomes smaller with time and then completely disappears after 210 s in the channel.
Fig. 7
Successive snapshots 10, 120, and 210 s after placing the droplet on the coated channel

To investigate the durability of the hydrophilic character of the channel coating, the chip was cut into two parts perpendicular to the coated channel. We have again followed the flow kinetics of water droplets into the freshly coated part. The experiment was repeated on the second part after 16 months (data not shown) and shows that the droplet flows in the channel and finally disappears over similar time period.
Next, we have investigated the effect of channel coating on dye contamination of the chips and thus possible cross-contamination of bacteria solutions.

Figures 8, 9 show the measured fluorescence intensity from SYTO13 as a function of position along a cross section of a channel obtained with pure PBS buffer (reference), after full 1 ml solution injection (time = 55 min) and after flushing with 1 ml buffer (time = 120 min), for both the uncoated (Fig. 8) and coated (Fig. 9) PDMS chips.
Fig. 8
Linescans of light intensity across a sample channel of a non-coated PDMS chip. The peaks at 725 and 880 μm refer to the side walls of the microfluidic channel
Fig. 9
Linescans of light intensity across a sample channel of a PVA–ZnO coated PDMS chip. The peaks at 725 and 880 μm refer to the side walls of the microfluidic channel

In both cases, the amount of SYTO13 on the channel walls (peaks on right- and left-hand side) clearly builds up during injection (solid black curves), while the final level after flushing is considerably lower for the coated chip (dashed red curves). The plots furthermore indicate that no dye diffuses out into the PDMS matrix itself as the background intensity outside the channels does not change during injection. Rather, the dye builds up on the wall interface (peaks on the left- and right-hand sides).
Within the channel, the effect of coating is negligible apart from a small increase in surface roughness.

Figure 10 shows how the intensity of the left-hand side peak (at 725 μm) changes during the injection and flushing cycles for both the coated and uncoated chips. It is clearly seen that the coating allows reducing the amount of dye contamination significantly at the wall interface by flushing.
Fig. 10
Light intensity at wall interface as a function of time during the injection and flushing cycles for both coated and uncoated PDMS chips

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In this article, we have presented a method to coat all PDMS microfluidic chips with integrated fluid and optical connectors in situ with fluorescence dye repelling PVA–ZnO nanocomposite layers.
The most direct application of these chips is in biosensing methods that use dye staining of active compounds for selective and most sensitive optical detection.

The risk of cross-contamination between samples is significantly reduced with the present ZnO–PVA nanocomposite coating. Less time and less cleaning solution is needed for rinsing the chips between measurements.
